{/* Hero Section */}
A01:2021

Broken Access Control

Restrictions on what authenticated users are allowed to do are not properly enforced. Attackers can exploit these flaws to access unauthorized functionality or data.

HIGH SEVERITY OWASP Rank: #1
{/* Overview Section */}

Overview

Access control enforces policy such that users cannot act outside of their intended permissions. Failures typically lead to unauthorized information disclosure, modification, or destruction of all data or performing a business function outside the user's limits.

Common Attack Vectors

  • Vertical privilege escalation
  • Horizontal privilege escalation
  • Business logic abuse
  • IDOR (Insecure Direct Object Reference)

Prevalence

94%

of applications tested

Impact

High

Technical Impact

Exploitability

Average

Attack Difficulty

{/* Examples Section */}

Real-World Examples

IDOR Attack

Changing the URL parameter from /user/profile/123 to /user/profile/124 to access another user's data without authorization.

Privilege Escalation

A regular user accessing admin functionality by modifying hidden form fields or API requests to gain elevated privileges.

Metadata Manipulation

Modifying JWT tokens or replaying sessions to impersonate other users or gain unauthorized access to protected resources.

{/* Prevention Section */}

Prevention Measures

1

Implement Proper Authorization

Ensure all API endpoints and web routes have proper authorization checks before processing requests.

2

Use Access Control Lists

Implement ACLs to define and enforce user permissions based on roles and responsibilities.

3

Validate User Permissions

Always verify user permissions on the server-side, never rely on client-side validation alone.

4

Implement Rate Limiting

Prevent brute force attacks by limiting the number of requests users can make to sensitive endpoints.

{/* Resources Section */}

Additional Resources
